posts.text: No, that's just how density works. there is a limit to how densely packed together stuff can be. That limit is roughly how things are packed in the nucleus of an atom. If you pack the mass of a star at that density, you get a neutron star or a black hole. That's just how density works.

posts.text:
The density of a black hole is on the order of 10^13-10^15 g/cm^3. 

Atoms that carry electrons are extremely low density. The NUCLEUS of an atom is dense.

chem.libretexts.org/Ancillary_Ma...

reply_context.text:
The radius of an atom is fuzzy; we get to define where we say it ends.
Gas giants can hit 1.6 g/cm^3.
Asteroids vary from 0.5 to 2 g/cm^3.
Pluto has a density of 1.85 g/cm^3
The sun has a density of 1.4 g/cm^3
A 140 million solar mass black hole has the density of water af 0.3 au radius.

posts.text: Newsrooms gravitate towards relying on advertising revenue, pushing their priorities towards attention economy incentives. Independent journalists are producing a lot of value *right now*: we need to find a model to protect and sustain them. Shoehorning them into the old model clearly isn't it.

reply_context.text: I mean journalists should be organizing into newsrooms, instead of everyone being totally independent. Worker-owned, smallish groups. They can pool resources, afford editors and fact checkers and etc.

posts.text:
